title: Whole-Grain Stuffing With Kale and Dried Fruit
recipe_yield: 6 to 8 cups, enough for a 12-pound bird

title: All-Butter Pie Crust
description: Some people shy away from making pie crusts. Here is a recipe to banish all fear, a simple dough of butter and all-purpose flour, easy to make and dependable as can be. If you plan to make a pie with a top crust, double the recipe; when it's time to chill the dough, divide it in half and shape into two disks to put in the fridge. The dough will also keep for 3 months in the freezer, if you want to stash a few disks thre. Defrost in the fridge overnight.

title: Honey Apple Pie With Thyme
description: This recipe elevates the standard American classic into something a little loftier: two types of apples, swathed in a caramelized glaze of honey and thyme, tempered with a bit of ginger and salt. Don't be intimidated by making crust – our

title: Pear-Pomegranate Pie
description: In this welcome departure from the traditional apple pie, a combination of Anjou and Bosc pears are caramelized in a mixture of pomegranate molasses and butter, then combined with a smaller portion of fresh, uncooked pears. The whole glorious mess is then dumped into an all-butter crust and baked until tender. The happy result is a pie that's soft and sweet, tangy and toothsome, and oh so good. (Don't let making your own pie crust intimidate you: our

title: Brandied Pumpkin and Chestnut Pie
description: This is quite possibly the best pumpkin pie recipe out there. Why? It's got two layers (chestnut and pumpkin), and it calls for fresh squash in lieu of the canned stuff. Make

title: Nutmeg-Maple Cream Pie
description: This pie is a delicious twist on a custard standby, and it is exceedingly easy, a humble yet grandly flavored addition to any celebration. Don't let making your own pie crust intimidate you: our

title: Hashed Brussels Sprouts With Lemon
description: A shower of lemon zest and black mustard seeds on a fast sauté of hashed brussels sprouts makes a traditional side dish with unexpected, bright flavors. Slice the sprouts a day or so before (a food processor makes it easy) and refrigerate until it's time to prepare them.

description: This recipe require minimal attention on Thanksgiving Day. The apple triangles can be assembled up to a month ahead and frozen, since puff pastry is so packed with butter that it keeps perfectly.

Roast Turkey Breast
description: Roasting a whole turkey breast for Thanksgiving, rather than an entire bird, offers a few clear advantages. It cuts roasting time at least in half, reduces the hassle of carving, and frees you to create more interesting side dishes. But perhaps the best argument for roasting a breast is that you can produce white meat that is truly moist, as opposed to the dried-out white meat that results from roasting a whole turkey until the legs are cooked through. A breast of about three pounds is fine for a party of four, while one weighing six pounds or more can serve about 10. And yes, there are usually enough leftovers for sandwiches.

title: Sautéed Kale With Garlic and Olive Oil
description: This recipe from 1992 was ahead of the curve on the kale trend. It gives a good basic preparation for this now ubiquitous leafy green: trim, blanch, drain, sautée (do not overcook), then serve immediately and often.

title: Gratin of Celery Roots And Chestnuts
45-Minute Roast Turkey
description: In 2002, Mark Bittman published this revolutionary approach to roasting the Thanksgiving turkey, which allows you to cut the cooking time of the average turkey by about 75 percent while still presenting an attractive bird. Simply cut out the backbone — or ask your butcher to do it for you — and spread the bird out flat before roasting, a technique known as spatchcocking that is commonly used with chickens. Roasted at 450 degrees, a 10-pound bird will be done in about 45 minutes. Really. It will also be more evenly browned (all of the skin is exposed to the heat), more evenly cooked, and moister than birds cooked conventionally.

description: It may be Thanksgiving, but to make pumpkin pie is a relatively thankless task. Always invited but often ignored, most pumpkin pies are too heavy to enjoy after a large dinner. Yet the meal is somehow incomplete without it.

title: Jalapeño Corn Bread Stuffing
recipe_yield: 14 cups. Enough for 12 to 14 lb turkey

title: Cardoon Soup With Coddled Oysters And Oyster Mushrooms

title: Tuna Steaks, With Anchovy Tomato Sauce
Cranberry Parker House Rolls
description: Here's a delightful, tangy twist on the fluffy breadbasket staple; cranberry butter is brushed between two layers of dough then baked until golden. They're fun, they're unexpected, they're delicious. (Bonus: they can be made ahead and frozen up to two weeks before.)

title: Salami and Scallion Biscuits
description: These rich, savory biscuits are even better than the traditional ham and cheese variety. Bits of chopped salami and scallions are scattered throughout tender dough that's been enriched with heavy cream. Did we mention that they come together – start to finish – in about 45 minutes? They'll be gone in about five.

title: Linguine With Bay Scallops And Pancetta
Scallops With Potatoes And White Truffle Oil

Broccoli Rabe Salad With Roasted-Garlic Vinaigrette

Frozen Maple Mousse With Sauteed Maple Apples

Chickpea, Red Pepper And Celery Root Soup With Cilantro
Basic Chicken Soup
description: This recipe is adapted from “The Whole World Loves Chicken Soup” by our old colleague Mimi Sheraton. It was published in 1995. Practical and pragmatic in the technical aspects of soup making, Ms. Sheraton is an unabashed hedonist when it comes to serving and consuming it. "Chicken soup must be very, very hot," she counsels. "You want to have to inhale it, to take tiny sips at first and build, as the soup cools, to larger and larger bites. Near the end, you are racing to finish. Tepid soup is dead."

title: Sopa de Fideos (Mexican Chicken Noodle Soup)
description: This Mexican version of chicken noodle soup uses fideos, vermicelli or capellini for the noodles. It’s garnished with cilantro, green chiles, avocado and cheese.

title: Shrimp and Tomato Tartlets
description: This is not difficult to make if you are organized. I first prepared these while staying at the magnificent Chateau de Pray near the Loire Valley city of Amboise. This region is famous for crisp tart wines like Sancerre and the sweeter Vouvray, as well as cheese and freshwater fish and shellfish.

title: Poached Fillet of Beef With Winter Vegetables
Spinach With Pine Nuts And Raisins
Potatoes in Red Wine With Rosemary
Smoked Beef Tongue With Tomato-Horseradish Sauce
Roast Loin of Pork, With Prunes
James Beard's Compote Of Dried Fruits
Croquembouche de Noel
description: Layers of 9, 7 and 4 inches are needed. To make 9- and 4-inch layers, double following recipe. (Enough batter is left over for a 6-inch layer to be used for Yuletide Angel.)

ingredients: garlic, peeled, crushed, and finely chopped
mixed salad greens, rinsed and thoroughly dried

title: Sweet and Sour Red Cabbage and Apples
Kale, Bean, Potato And Sausage Soup
Sylvia's Fruitcake
description: This cake is especially appealing to those who do not care for even the best quality candied fruit. It is more dried fruits and nuts than cake.

title: White House Fruitcake
description: Pastry chef Roland Mesnier has updated the version of the fruitcake made at the White House for many years.

title: Easy Cakeless Fruitcake
description: For those who prefer fruits and nuts to batter, and very little work, this simple cake is appropriately named.

title: Whisky Cake
description: For those whose interest in dried fruits extends only as far as raisins, this whisky cake is a near fruitcake.

title: Pizza Bread With Truffle Oil and Salmon
Madeline Sorel Bread Pudding From Nancy Silverton At Maxwell's Plum
Indoor S’mores
description: You may not have a grill or the weather may not be cooperating, but you can still revel in this childhood favorite, and it's a brilliant way to make s'mores for a crowd. Also brilliant: melted chocolate is spread on both of the graham crackers for each s'more, so the chocolate envelops the marshmallow with each bite.

title: Fillets of Flounder With Parsley and Mustard Sauce
Swordfish Roll-Ups As Prepared In Messina
Pasta With Bread Crumbs And Anchovies As Prepared In Syracuse, Sicily
Guacamole
description: This guacamole is the definitive recipe, adapted from Josefina Howard, the chef at the original Rosa Mexicano restaurant in Manhattan. It is dead simple and easily scaled to serve a crowd, which is good, because you'll need a lot of it — even if you're the only one partaking.

title: Green Bean, Chevre And Pignoli Nut Salad
Celery Root, Endive, Avocado And Blue Crab Salad
Grilled Salmon on a Bed Of Apple Bulgur
Brussels Sprouts With Herbes de Provence
Roast Suckling Pig With Sage-Apple Stuffing
description: Of all meat dishes, perhaps suckling pig most strongly suggests celebration. The well-roasted pig with its shiny amber skin and moist, distinctive-tasting meat always makes for a memorable meal. Many home cooks are intimidated by this dish, but there really is no reason; and for those concerned about fat in the diet, the young pig has less body fat than more mature meats.

title: Stuffed Saddle of Lamb With Gravy
Crown Roast of Pork With Spicy Rice Stuffing

title: Minestrone
description: One of my favorite dishes, which is hard to find properly made in Italian restaurants, is a good minestrone. This hardy vegetable soup is especially delicious poured on top of a mound of steamed Swiss chard or kale, and garnished with a green extra virgin Tuscan olive oil and freshly grated Parmesan. If you have any leftover rinds of Parmesan cheese, they can be cooked in the soup and will give it flavor. Serve the soup with toasted Italian bread spread with olive oil and rubbed with crushed garlic.

title: Carrots in Cream and Mustard Sauce
Alfred Portale's Christmas Turkey Sandwich
description: Diners flock to the Gotham Bar and Grill to eat the chef Alfred Portale’s elegant towers of beautiful food. But on the day after a turkey holiday, he’s just like the rest of us, making sandwiches with leftover meat. Here he combines turkey and stuffing along with lettuce, tomato, thin-sliced red onion and an elegant homemade mayonnaise on crusty Italian bread to update the old white-bread and dark meat special we’ve all had so many times. Adding a smear of cranberry sauce would not be an error.
